TADS 3
Adv3Lite Bookshelf Adv3 Bookshelf Cheat Sheets

Landing with a Running Start!

A quickstart guide for TADS 3

Please choose your operating system and preferred software:

WINDOWS
Workbench
VSCode

MAC
VSCode

LINUX
VSCode
Terminal  ( vim / emacs / etc )

Windows

Install for Workbench

Text here.

Install for VSCode

Text here.

MacOS

Install for VSCode

For MacOS, you will need to install FrobTADS, which provides you with many of the crucial tools necessary for creating TADS games outside of Windows.

(These instructions are partially based on a text file written by Reg, which was included in the FrobTADS download. None of the creators of this site have access to a Mac, so a lot of research was done to write this, without any direct testing or experience.)

  1. Open Finder, and navigate to Applications.
  2. Open the Utilities folder.
  3. Run Terminal.app, and also drag it to the dock for easier access in the future.
  4. For those unaccustomed to the Terminal, Reg provides the following message:

    Using terminal, you are always located somewhere inside your computer. For instance, you could be inside your applications folder, or perhaps your itunes folder... but it's important to know where you are because this affects how commands could be interpreted.

    Some common commands:
    CHANGING DIRECTORY
    • $cd
      Change directory (This is how you navigate around in your computer).
    • $/Applications
      The slash refers to a folder, the name after the slash is the name of a folder.
    • $cd /Applications
      This is how you would enter the Applications folder.
    • $cd /Applications/Utilities
      This is how you would enter the utilities folder.
    • $.
      A dot means "current folder".
    • $..
      Two dots mean "one folder before".
    • $cd ../
      Means move to the previous folder.

    Try the cd command with different folders to get a feel for navigating.

    If any folders have spaces in them, things are a little more complicated. You can drag a file or folder into the "terminal" window and it will show how you would type the location of the file or folder.

    FINDING A FILE ( Includes hidden files which spotlight won't show you )
    • $cd /
      Changes directories so you're located in the top-most directory.
    • $find . -name adv3.h
      Searches for a file called "adv3.h".
    OTHER COMMANDS
    • $tar -xzf
      Expand a *.tar.gz compressed archive.
    • $ls
      List all files in a folder, except hidden files.
    • $ls -a
      List everything in a folder, including hidden files.
    • $sudo
      This command is added to the beginning of a command if it's something where you need to have administrative (root) access.

    A list of more commands
    A very good unix beginner page is here

    By the way:
    The word binary generally means compiled file as opposed to the source code which is the building blocks of a file.

  5. Install Xcode Tools.

    Reg says:

    This is on your install DVD that came with your mac but it's better to download the newest version via the internet.

    This is free when you make an ADC [or Apple Developer] account (account is also free).

    Follow the installation instructions that come with it.

  6. Head to the download site for Homebrew, and download the pkg installer.
  7. Double-click on the Homebrew pkg file to install it.
  8. If you have Terminal open, close it and open a new one. Otherwise, open Terminal.app now.
  9. Enter this command: $echo $PATH
  10. What will appear is a list of folder paths, where each step in the path is separated by a / (slash), and each path is separated by a : (colon). Search through the paths, and make sure you find one that says /usr/local/bin.

    If you do find this, skip to step 15.
  11. Open your home folder in Finder.
  12. Look for a file called .bashrc. If you do not see it in your home folder, press SHIFT + CMD + ..

    Open .bashrc with TextEdit.

    Make sure TextEdit is using plain text by pressing SHIFT + CMD + T!
  13. Scroll to the bottom of the file, and add the following line:
  14. Save and close the text file.
  15. Close the terminal.
  16. Open a new terminal, and run $brew install cmake ncurses.
  17. Close the terminal.
  18. Download the latest FrobTADS source code.
  19. Reg says:
    Your computer will probably automatically decompress these items. If it hasn't done so for the frobtads folder, double-click on the disk image so it decompresses.
  20. Move the decompressed frobtads-2.0 folder to your home folder.
  21. Start Terminal.app, and run $cd ~/frobtads-2.0.
  22. Make sure you are actually in the folder. $ls should list filenames such as:
    • CMakeLists.txt
    • CMCommon.cmake
    • etc...
    If you only see frobtads-2.0, then try $cd frobtads-2.0 && ls to repeat this verification step.
  23. $mkdir build
  24. $cd build
  25. Simply run $cmake ..
  26. Finally, run the compile process with this command:
    $sudo cmake --build . --target install
  27. If the research and efforts of the writer of this guide have paid off, then the compilation process should be successful, and you will have a new Terminal.app command at your disposal: $t3make, which is used to compile new TADS 3 games from your game project folders.

Linux

Install for VSCode

For Linux, you will need to install FrobTADS, which provides you with many of the crucial tools necessary for creating TADS games outside of Windows.

  1. Open a terminal with CTRL + ALT + T.
  2. Make sure to update your system before beginning this process.
    • Ubuntu/Debian
      $sudo apt update
      $sudo apt upgrade
    • Fedora/CentOS
      $sudo dnf check-update
      $sudo dnf update
  3. Install the necessary packages.
    • Ubuntu/Debian
      $ sudo apt install cmake g++ make libncurses5-dev libncursesw5-dev
    • Fedora/CentOS
      $ sudo dnf install cmake gcc-c++ make ncurses-devel
  4. Ubuntu/Debian only:
    If the package is missing, you can install it with $sudo apt install curl.
  5. Ubuntu/Debian only:
    Check to verify libcurl is installed. This can be done with $curl-config --version.
  6. Ubuntu/Debian only:
    If the package is missing, or verification returned some kind of error, then the package needs to be installed. Ubuntu/Debian distros have a choice between three alternative versions of this library. If the choice does not matter to you, then go with the openssl version. For those who might have a preference, the choices are the following:
    • $sudo apt install libcurl4-openssl-dev
    • $sudo apt install libcurl4-nss-dev
    • $sudo apt install libcurl4-gnutls-dev
  7. CentOS only:
    CentOS comes with a minimal version of curl installed. If there are errors related to curl later (during compilation), then you might need to install the full versions with $sudo dnf install curl-full libcurl-full
  8. Fedora only:
    Fedora users will need to verify curl and its dev libraries, but the latter can be installed by running $sudo yum install libcurl-devel
  9. Download and extract a copy of the latest FrobTADS source code.
    (It is recommended to move the extracted frobtads-2.0 directory to your home ~ directory.)
  10. Navigate to the extracted directory through your terminal. For example: $cd ~/frobtads-2.0
  11. Make sure you are actually in the directory. $ls should list filenames such as:
    • CMakeLists.txt
    • CMCommon.cmake
    • etc...
    If you only see frobtads-2.0, then try $cd frobtads-2.0 && ls to repeat this verification step.
  12. $mkdir build
  13. $cd build
  14. Next, we will prepare the compiler by choosing where the resulting binaries will go. By default, the installation prefix is /usr/local, which places the binaries into /usr/local/bin/, making them available as terminal commands.
    1. Default installation path
      Simply run $cmake ..
    2. Custom installation path
      You can choose which directory the binaries will be installed to by changing the -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<path-prefix> option.
      Notice that this prefix is set in two places in this command:
      $ CFLAGS="-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local" CXXFLAGS="-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local" cmake ..
  15. Finally, run the compile process with this command:
    $sudo cmake --build . --target install
    If your custom installation prefix does not require root privileges for write operations, then sudo is unnecessary for this command.
  16. Assuming the compile process is successful, you will have two new binaries, which will become particularly useful:
    • $frob MyNewGame.t3 for playing TADS game files in the terminal, and
    • $t3make in a project directory for compiling TADS 3 games.
  17. Download and extract the latest version of Adv3Lite from Eric Eve's GitHub.
  18. Navigate to the extracted directory through your terminal. For example: $cd ~/adv3Lite
  19. Make sure you are actually in the directory. $ls should list filenames such as:
    • action.t
    • actions.t
    • etc...
    If you only see adv3Lite, then try $cd adv3Lite && ls to repeat this verification step.
  20. Once we are certain we are at the correct directory depth, run $cd .., followed by $sudo mv ./adv3Lite /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/adv3Lite, which will move adv3Lite into your TADS library directory.
    The destination path may vary if you used a custom installation prefix; these instructions assume you have used a prefix of /usr/local.
  1. Assuming you already have VSCode installed, start it up.
  2. Install these extensions:
    1. vscode-tads3tools by Tomas Öberg, and
    2. Code Spell Checker by Street Side Software
  3. Go to File > Preferences > Settings.
  4. Enter tads into the settings search bar, and click on the Tads category, under Extensions.
  5. Verify that Tads > Preprocessor: Path and Tads3 > Compiler: Path are both set to run the t3make binary.
  6. Verify that you have the Adv3 and Adv3Lite libraries installed. If you had compiled with the /usr/local prefix, then they should be under /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/adv3/ and /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/adv3Lite/, respectively.
  7. Verify that Tads3: Include points to your TADS 3 include files. If you had compiled with the /usr/local prefix, then they should be under /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/include/.
  8. Verify that Tads3: Lib points to your TADS 3 library files. If you had compiled with the /usr/local prefix, then they should be under /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/.
  9. Verify that Tads3 > Adv3: Library points to your TADS 3 Adv3 directory. If you had compiled with the /usr/local prefix, then they should be under /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/adv3/.
  10. Verify that Tads3 > Adv3 Lite: Library points to your TADS 3 Adv3Lite directory. If you had compiled with the /usr/local prefix, then they should be under /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/adv3Lite/.
  11. Verify that Tads3: Game Runner Interpreter is set to run your preferred TADS 3 interpreter. For example, if you are using QTADS to play games, you might have this set to something like /home/username-here/Desktop/QTads/QTads.AppImage.
  12. Optional
    Enable Tads3: Restart Game Runner On T3 Image Changes if you would like your specified interpreter to re-open your game each time changes are made to your project.
  13. Close the Settings tab.
  14. Press CTRL + SHIFT + P to open your command search bar, and type in create a new Tads3 template project. Select the top result to run it.
  15. A dialog window will open, where you must select your game's project directory.
  16. Once the project directory is set, you will asked to choose either an Adv3 project template, or an Adv3Lite project template.
  17. A basic template will be generated in the project directory. Each time you save a file in your project, t3make will be run automatically. It will use the compile options specified in Makefile.t3m, and the game file will usually be named gameMain.t3, unless you specify otherwise in the makefile. The source file, by default, will be named gameMain.t.
  18. Optional
    Create a bash script named run.sh and give it the following code: Then, do $chmod +x run.sh. You can run this script to re-open your game, if you did not choose to automatically perform this with every saved change: $./run.sh
  19. Open gameMain.t, if it's not open already. It's contents should resemble the following:
    For an Adv3 template For an Adv3Lite template
  20. Open Makefile.t3m. It's contents should resemble the following:
    For an Adv3 template For an Adv3Lite template
  21. At this point, your game should be ready to run! Read the documentation for the library you chose for your game, and create the rest of your project. Happy coding!

Install for Terminal

For Linux, you will need to install FrobTADS, which provides you with many of the crucial tools necessary for creating TADS games outside of Windows.

  1. Open a terminal with CTRL + ALT + T.
  2. Make sure to update your system before beginning this process.
    • Ubuntu/Debian
      $sudo apt update
      $sudo apt upgrade
    • Fedora/CentOS
      $sudo dnf check-update
      $sudo dnf update
  3. Install the necessary packages.
    • Ubuntu/Debian
      $ sudo apt install cmake g++ make libncurses5-dev libncursesw5-dev
    • Fedora/CentOS
      $ sudo dnf install cmake gcc-c++ make ncurses-devel
  4. Ubuntu/Debian only:
    If the package is missing, you can install it with $sudo apt install curl.
  5. Ubuntu/Debian only:
    Check to verify libcurl is installed. This can be done with $curl-config --version.
  6. Ubuntu/Debian only:
    If the package is missing, or verification returned some kind of error, then the package needs to be installed. Ubuntu/Debian distros have a choice between three alternative versions of this library. If the choice does not matter to you, then go with the openssl version. For those who might have a preference, the choices are the following:
    • $sudo apt install libcurl4-openssl-dev
    • $sudo apt install libcurl4-nss-dev
    • $sudo apt install libcurl4-gnutls-dev
  7. CentOS only:
    CentOS comes with a minimal version of curl installed. If there are errors related to curl later (during compilation), then you might need to install the full versions with $sudo dnf install curl-full libcurl-full
  8. Fedora only:
    Fedora users will need to verify curl and its dev libraries, but the latter can be installed by running $sudo yum install libcurl-devel
  9. Download and extract a copy of the latest FrobTADS source code.
    (It is recommended to move the extracted frobtads-2.0 directory to your home ~ directory.)
  10. Navigate to the extracted directory through your terminal. For example: $cd ~/frobtads-2.0
  11. Make sure you are actually in the directory. $ls should list filenames such as:
    • CMakeLists.txt
    • CMCommon.cmake
    • etc...
    If you only see frobtads-2.0, then try $cd frobtads-2.0 && ls to repeat this verification step.
  12. $mkdir build
  13. $cd build
  14. Next, we will prepare the compiler by choosing where the resulting binaries will go. By default, the installation prefix is /usr/local, which places the binaries into /usr/local/bin/, making them available as terminal commands.
    1. Default installation path
      Simply run $cmake ..
    2. Custom installation path
      You can choose which directory the binaries will be installed to by changing the -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=<path-prefix> option.
      Notice that this prefix is set in two places in this command:
      $ CFLAGS="-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local" CXXFLAGS="-DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local" cmake ..
  15. Finally, run the compile process with this command:
    $sudo cmake --build . --target install
    If your custom installation prefix does not require root privileges for write operations, then sudo is unnecessary for this command.
  16. Assuming the compile process is successful, you will have two new binaries, which will become particularly useful:
    • $frob MyNewGame.t3 for playing TADS game files in the terminal, and
    • $t3make in a project directory for compiling TADS 3 games.
  17. Download and extract the latest version of Adv3Lite from Eric Eve's GitHub.
  18. Navigate to the extracted directory through your terminal. For example: $cd ~/adv3Lite
  19. Make sure you are actually in the directory. $ls should list filenames such as:
    • action.t
    • actions.t
    • etc...
    If you only see adv3Lite, then try $cd adv3Lite && ls to repeat this verification step.
  20. Once we are certain we are at the correct directory depth, run $cd .., followed by $sudo mv ./adv3Lite /usr/local/share/frobtads/tads3/lib/adv3Lite, which will move adv3Lite into your TADS library directory.
    The destination path may vary if you used a custom installation prefix; these instructions assume you have used a prefix of /usr/local.
  1. For the rest of this guide, there will no specific instructions for your editor of choice, so it is assumed you are using something with capabilities equal to—or surpassing—the nano terminal-based text editor.

    At this point, create a new project directory for your game, and navigate into it.
  2. Decide at this time if you are using either the Adv3 or Adv3Lite library for your game.
  3. Create your first source file: gameMain.t.
    For an Adv3 template For an Adv3Lite template
  4. Create your project makefile: Makefile.t3m.
    For an Adv3 template For an Adv3Lite template
  5. Create a directory named obj in your game project directory. This can be done with $mkdir obj.
  6. To compile your game, run $t3make.
  7. Create a bash script named run.sh and give it the following code: Then, do $chmod +x run.sh.
  8. At this point, your game should be ready to run! Read the documentation for the library you chose for your game, and create the rest of your project. Happy coding!
  9. To test your game, execute $./run.sh.

TADS is Copyright ©2001-2013 Michael J. Roberts. We do not claim authorship over, or any rights to, TADS 3 itself.

This is an unofficial informational website made by fans of the TADS 3 authoring system in an attempt to spread the word about what we believe to be an underappreciated system, and provide a repository for more up to date information than is contained on the original tads.org website, which hasn't been updated since roughly 2013. For more information, however, definitely go check out that website too, as there is a lot of content there that we haven't covered here, just as there is content here not covered there.
